## **Phonetics and Phonology**
<br>
.pull-left[<br><br><img src="../pic/1107/read.png" width="90%">]
.pull-right[
Now we're looking at the smallest element of language: **sounds**<br><br>
Phonetics and Phonology studies the **sounds** of language<br><br>
- **Phonetics**: study of speech sounds as a physical phenomenon<br><br>
- **Phonology**: study of how languages organize speech sounds into a system (pattern)
]


---
## **Vowels**
<br>
.pull-left[
**vowels** vs. <span style="color:green"><b>consonants</b></span> vs. <span style="color:blue"><b>glides</b></span><br>
- whether airflow is obstructed somewhere
  - **vowels** - no obstruction
  - <span style="color:green"><b>consonants</b></span> - with obstruction
  - <span style="color:blue"><b>glides</b></span> - somewhere between **vowels** and <span style="color:green"><b>consonants</b></span> <br><br>

**vowel articulation**
- tongue <span style="color:green"><b>height</b></span>
  - high, mid, low
- tongue <span style="color:green"><b>backness</b></span>
  - front, central, back
- lip <span style="color:green"><b>roundness</b></span>
  - rounded, unrounded
- tense and lax (**lax**: relaxed tongue))
]
.pull-right[<br><br><img src="../pic/1107/avowels.png" width="95%">]

## **Other Vowel Features**
.pull-left[
<br><br>
<img src="../pic/1107/morning.jpeg" width="95%">
]
.pull-right[
**nasalization**: articulated by lowering the velum/soft palate, so that air flows through both the **nasal** and **oral** cavity

- <span style="color:green"><b>English</b></span><br>
<span style="color:blue"><b>æ</b></span>t '*at*' **vs.** <span style="color:blue"><b>æ̃</b></span>nt '*ant*'<br><br>

**length**: long vowels **contrast** with short vowels
- <span style="color:green"><b>Mongolian</b></span><br>
[t͡s<span style="color:blue"><b>ɑ</b></span>ˈsɯn] '*snow*' **vs.** [t͡s<span style="color:blue"><b>ɑɑ</b></span>ˈsɯn] '*paper*'
- since adding or removing the **length feature** changes the meaning completely, we say that length is **contrastive** in mongolian
<br><br>

**pitch**: tonal languages **contrast** pitch
- <span style="color:green"><b>Mandarin Chinese</b></span><br>
ma<sup><span style="color:blue"><b>55</b></span></sup>
<span style="color:white"><b>----</b></span>
ma<sup><span style="color:blue"><b>35</b></span></sup>
<span style="color:white"><b>----</b></span>
ma<sup><span style="color:blue"><b>214</b></span></sup>
<span style="color:white"><b>----</b></span>
ma<sup><span style="color:blue"><b>51</b></span></sup><br>
'*mom*'<span style="color:white"><b>--</b></span>
'*numb*'<span style="color:white"><b>--</b></span>
'*horse*'<span style="color:white"><b>----</b></span>
'*scold*'
]

## **Sounds vs. Spellings**
<br>
.pull-left[
- **spelling** (orthography) has a problem: one sound doesn't always equal one letter <br><br>

- two letters, one sound
  - *<span style="color:green"><b>th</b></span>* and *<span style="color:green"><b>ng</b></span>* in *<span style="color:green"><b>th</b></span>i<span style="color:green"><b>ng</b></span>*
- one letter, two sounds
  - *<span style="color:orange"><b>x</b></span>* in *ta<span style="color:orange"><b>x</b></span>*
- one letter, no sound
  - *<span style="color:red"><b>k</b></span>*, *<span style="color:red"><b>g</b></span>*, and *<span style="color:red"><b>h</b></span>* in *<span style="color:red"><b>k</b></span>ni<span style="color:red"><b>gh</b></span>t* 
- one sound, many spellings
  - *ru<span style="color:pink"><b>sh</b></span>*, *no<span style="color:pink"><b>t</b></span>ion*, *o<span style="color:pink"><b>c</b></span>ean*, *ni<span style="color:pink"><b>ch</b></span>e*, *i<span style="color:pink"><b>ss</b></span>ue*, *<span style="color:pink"><b>sch</b></span>lep*, *fu<span style="color:pink"><b>chs</b></span>ia*
- one spelling, many sounds
  - *thr<span style="color:blue"><b>ou</b></span>gh* ≠ *pl<span style="color:blue"><b>ou</b></span>gh* ≠ *<span style="color:blue"><b>ou</b></span>ght* ≠ *r<span style="color:blue"><b>ou</b></span>gh* ≠ *c<span style="color:blue"><b>ou</b></span>gh* ≠ *th<span style="color:blue"><b>ou</b></span>gh*
]
.pull-right[
<br><br><br>
<img src="../pic/1107/fish.jpg" width="90%">
]

---
## **Sounds vs. Spellings**
.pull-left[
<br><br>
<img src="../pic/1107/ex.jpg" width="95%">
]
.pull-right[
- no language has a writing system that can **perfectly** represent its speech sounds<br><br>
- pronunciation **changes over time**; writing doesn't always reflect these changes<br>*knight*, *time*
- pronunciation **varies by place and social group**; writing doesn't usually reflect this<br>*schedule*, *cot*/*caught*
- **loanwords** (words borrowed from another language) often have spellings that reflect the pronunciation in the source language, not target language<br>*zucchini*, *psychology*<br><br>
- this becomes a problem when we want to talk precisely about **phonetics**, and we want to accurately represent the **pronunciation**
]

## **International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)**<br>
### [ˌɪnəɹˈnæʃənəl fəˈnɛɾɪk ˈælfəˌbɛt]
<br>
.pull-left[
- to **accurately** represent speech sounds, we use the **International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)**
  - one symbol **=** one sound<br><br>
- same symbols for **all** spoken languages – all languages use some **subset** of these symbols (plus additional symbols on the full IPA chart)<br><br>
- many IPA symbols represent roughly the same sounds as the corresponding English letter
  - [p, t, k, b, d, g, f, v, s, z, h, m, n, l]<br><br>
- some IPA symbols do not
  - IPA [**j**] = English y, *yes* [jɛs]
  - [**c**, **q**, **x**] & most vowels ≠ English letters
]
.pull-right[
<br><br><br>
<img src="../pic/1107/ipa.png" width="100%">
]

---
## **International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)**<br>
.pull-left[
<br>
[<span style="color:brown"><b>ˌ</b></span>ɪnəɹ<span style="color:brown"><b>ˈ</b></span>næʃənəl fə<span style="color:brown"><b>ˈ</b></span>nɛɾɪk <span style="color:brown"><b>ˈ</b></span>ælfə<span style="color:brown"><b>ˌ</b></span>bɛt]
<br><br>
<img src="../pic/1107/schwa.jpg" width="80%">
]
.pull-right[
IPA is used for **phonetic transcription** – writing the exact sounds of a speech sample <br><br>

some **conventions**
- phonetic transcriptions are put between **square brackets [</b></span>**bə.ˈnæ.nə**]**
- spelling (orthography) is written in *<span style="color:green"><b>italics</b></span>* or <span style="color:green"><b>angle brackets</b></span>: *banana*, <span style="color:green"><b>&lt;b&gt;</b></span>
- <span style="color:blue"><b>all</b></span> sounds and <span style="color:blue"><b>only</b></span> sounds are written:
<br><br>
  - no silent letters<br>
  <span style="color:blue"><b>ph</b></span>on<span style="color:blue"><b>e</b></span> [ˈfown]; throu<span style="color:blue"><b>gh</b></span> [ˈθɹu]
  - write out actually pronounced sounds<br>
  ne<span style="color:blue"><b>x</b></span>t [ˈnɛkst], e<span style="color:blue"><b>x</b></span>am [əɡ.ˈzæm]
<br><br>
- a dot (.) indicates <span style="color:orange"><b>syllable divisions</b></span>: pronunciation [prə<span style="color:orange"><b>.</b></span>ˌnʌn<span style="color:orange"><b>.</b></span>si<span style="color:orange"><b>.</b></span>ˈej<span style="color:orange"><b>.</b></span>ʃən]
- <span style="color:brown"><b>primary</b></span> and <span style="color:brown"><b>secondary</b></span> stress are indicated with <span style="color:brown"><b>ˈ</b></span> and <span style="color:brown"><b>ˌ</b></span> <span style="color:brown"><b>before</b></span> the stressed syllable

]
